question_text: According to 14 CFR part 107 the remote pilot in command (PIC) of a small unmanned aircraft planning to operate within Class C airspace

options.text: is required to file a flight plan.
is required to receive ATC authorization.

explanation_correct: Under 14 CFR 107.41, the remote PIC must receive ATC authorization before operating in Class B, C, or D airspace, or within the lateral boundaries of the surface area of Class E airspace designated for an airport.

explanation_distractors.A: A visual observer is not required for Class C operations — ATC authorization is the requirement.
explanation_distractors.B: Part 107 does not require filing a flight plan. The requirement is prior ATC authorization.

question_text: (Refer to FAA-CT-8080-2H, Figure 23, area 3.) What is the floor of the Savannah Class C airspace at the shelf area (outer circle)?
explanation_correct: The outer shelf of the Savannah Class C airspace has a floor of 1,300 feet MSL, as indicated on the sectional chart. Airspace altitudes on sectional charts are always expressed in MSL unless specifically noted as AGL.

explanation_distractors.A: Airspace dimensions on sectional charts are given in MSL, not AGL.
explanation_distractors.C: 1,700 feet MSL represents a different airspace boundary, not the outer shelf floor.

question_text: (Refer to FAA-CT-8080-2H, Figure 21.) You have been hired by a farmer to use your small UA to inspect his crops. The area that you are to survey is in the Devil's Lake West MOA, east of area 2. How would you find out if the MOA is active?

options.text: This information is available in the Small UAS database.
Refer to the Military Operations Directory.

explanation_correct: MOA activity information can be found by referring to the chart legend on the sectional chart, which provides the controlling agency contact information. The specific times of use and contact frequencies are listed in the Chart Supplements U.S. and on the sectional chart border information.

explanation_distractors.B: There is no 'Small UAS database' that provides real-time MOA activity information.
explanation_distractors.C: There is no publication called the 'Military Operations Directory.' The chart legend and Chart Supplements provide this information.

question_text: (Refer to FAA-CT-8080-2H, Figure 20, area 5.) How would a remote PIC "CHECK NOTAMS" as noted in the CAUTION box regarding the unmarked balloon?

options.text: By utilizing the B4UFLY mobile application.
By contacting the FAA district office.
By obtaining a briefing via an online source such as: 1800WXBrief.com.

explanation_correct: NOTAMs (Notices to Air Missions) can be obtained by getting a briefing from Flight Service via 1800WXBrief.com or by calling 1-800-WX-BRIEF. This is the official source for NOTAMs.

explanation_distractors.A: While B4UFLY provides some airspace information, it is not the primary source for NOTAMs. 1800WXBrief.com is the official source.
explanation_distractors.B: The FAA district office is not the standard resource for obtaining NOTAMs.

question_text: (Refer to FAA-CT-8080-2H, Figure 59, area 2.) The chart shows a gray line with "VR1667, VR1617, VR1638, and VR1668." Could this area present a hazard to the operations of a small UA?

options.text: No, all operations will be above 400 feet.
Yes, this is a Military Training Route from the surface to 1,500 feet AGL.
Yes, the defined route provides traffic separation to manned aircraft.

explanation_correct: VR routes (Visual Routes) with 4-digit numbers are Military Training Routes flown at or below 1,500 feet AGL. Military aircraft travel at high speeds at very low altitudes along these routes, posing a significant hazard to sUAS operations.

explanation_distractors.A: Military training routes include operations at low altitudes, well within the altitude range of sUAS operations.
explanation_distractors.C: Military Training Routes do not provide traffic separation — they are routes where fast-moving military aircraft operate at low altitudes.

question_text: Your surveying company is a title sponsor for a race team at the Indianapolis 500. To promote your new aerial surveying department, you decide to video part of the race using a small UA. The FAA has issued a Temporary Flight Restriction (TFR) for the race in the area you plan to fly. In this situation

options.text: you may fly your drone in the TFR since your company is sponsoring a team at the race.
the TFR applies to all aircraft; you may not fly in the area without a Certificate of Waiver or Authorization.
flying your drone is allowed if you notify all non-participating people of the closed course UA operation.

explanation_correct: TFRs apply to ALL aircraft, including small unmanned aircraft systems. You may not fly in an active TFR area without a Certificate of Waiver or Authorization (COA) from the FAA. Sponsorship of an event does not grant airspace access.

explanation_distractors.A: Sponsoring a team does not grant airspace privileges. TFRs apply to all aircraft regardless of affiliation.
explanation_distractors.C: Notifying people does not override a TFR. A COA is required.

question_text: (Refer to FAA-CT-8080-2H, Figure 26.) The Devils Lake East MOA (area 1) is a
explanation_correct: MOA stands for Military Operations Area. MOAs are airspace established to separate certain non-hazardous military activities from IFR traffic. Pilots should exercise extreme caution while flying within a MOA.

explanation_distractors.A: MOA does not stand for meteorological observation area.
explanation_distractors.B: MOA does not stand for military observation area — it is a Military Operations Area.

explanation_correct: UA.II.B.K8 corresponds to: Hazards on the ground that do not have lighting.

question_text: Which class of airspace does NOT require authorization from Air Traffic Control for small UAS operations?
explanation_correct: Class G airspace is uncontrolled airspace. No ATC authorization is required for small UAS operations in Class G airspace. All controlled airspace classes (B, C, D, and surface E) require prior ATC authorization via LAANC or a Part 107 waiver.

explanation_distractors.A: Class B requires ATC authorization under 14 CFR §107.41.
explanation_distractors.B: Class C requires ATC authorization under 14 CFR §107.41.
explanation_distractors.C: Class D requires ATC authorization under 14 CFR §107.41.

question_text: What class of airspace surrounds the nation's busiest airports, such as Atlanta Hartsfield-Jackson?
explanation_correct: Class B airspace surrounds the nation's busiest airports (e.g., Atlanta Hartsfield-Jackson, LAX, O'Hare). It is depicted on sectional charts by solid blue lines and typically extends from the surface to 10,000 ft MSL in a layered structure.

explanation_distractors.A: Class C surrounds airports with moderate traffic — depicted by solid magenta circles.
explanation_distractors.B: Class D surrounds smaller towered airports — depicted by dashed blue circles.
explanation_distractors.D: Class E is general controlled airspace, not specific to the busiest airports.

question_text: On a sectional chart, what does a magenta vignette (shaded area) around an airport indicate?

options.text: Class B airspace from the surface
Class C airspace from the surface
Class E airspace beginning at 700 ft AGL

explanation_correct: A magenta vignette (fading shading) around an airport on a sectional chart indicates Class E airspace that begins at 700 feet AGL. This is the transition area that supports IFR arrivals and departures at the airport.

explanation_distractors.A: Class B is depicted by solid blue lines, not a magenta vignette.
explanation_distractors.B: Class C surface area is depicted by solid magenta circles, not a vignette.
explanation_distractors.D: Class G is uncontrolled and is not depicted with a vignette.

question_text: What type of special use airspace is designed for high-density student pilot training activity but is NOT classified as controlled or restricted airspace?
explanation_correct: Alert Areas are depicted on aeronautical charts to inform pilots of areas that may contain a high volume of pilot training, unusual aerial activity, or other hazards. They are NOT restricted — you can fly through them but should exercise extreme caution.

explanation_distractors.A: Warning Areas contain hazards to nonparticipating aircraft but are located over international waters.
explanation_distractors.B: MOAs are used for military flight training and may be active or inactive — but are not student training focused.
explanation_distractors.C: Restricted Areas require ATC authorization and may be active or inactive.

question_text: What type of special use airspace designates areas where flight is prohibited due to national security or welfare reasons?
explanation_correct: Prohibited Areas contain airspace within which flight is prohibited for national security or other welfare reasons. Examples include the airspace over the White House (P-56) and Camp David. Flight in Prohibited Areas is never permitted without specific authorization.

explanation_distractors.A: Alert Areas are advisory in nature — they are not restricted or prohibited.
explanation_distractors.B: Restricted Areas may have hazardous activities but can sometimes be transited with ATC permission.
explanation_distractors.C: MOAs are used for military training and can often be transited when inactive.

question_text: On a sectional chart, a gray line with a four-digit route number indicates a Military Training Route (MTR). Could this present a hazard to small UAS operations?

options.text: No — MTRs only apply to high-altitude operations above 10,000 ft MSL
No — military aircraft always coordinate with FAA ATC before using MTRs
Yes — MTRs with four-digit numbers are flown at or below 1,500 ft AGL
Yes — but only when the route is active during published hours

explanation_correct: MTRs with four-digit numbers (e.g., IR1206, VR1001) are conducted at 1,500 ft AGL or below and at speeds exceeding 250 knots. This makes them a direct hazard to sUAS operations at low altitudes. Three-digit MTRs are flown above 1,500 ft AGL.

explanation_distractors.A: Incorrect — four-digit MTRs specifically operate at or below 1,500 ft AGL.
explanation_distractors.B: MTR coordination is internal to the military and does not involve real-time ATC advisories for sUAS operators.
explanation_distractors.D: MTRs can be flown any time and are not restricted to published hours.

question_text: An aircraft announces on CTAF that it is on short final for runway 9. In which direction will the aircraft be traveling, and from which direction is it approaching?

options.text: Traveling west, approaching from the east
Traveling east, approaching from the west
Traveling north, approaching from the south
Traveling south, approaching from the north

explanation_correct: Runway numbers correspond to magnetic heading rounded to the nearest 10 degrees. Runway 9 corresponds to a heading of 090° (east). An aircraft on short final for runway 9 is therefore flying toward the east and approaching from the west.

explanation_distractors.A: Runway 27 would be heading west — runway 9 is the opposite direction (east).
explanation_distractors.C: Runway 36 or 360 would be heading north.
explanation_distractors.D: Runway 18 would be heading south.

question_text: When approaching runway hold-short lines from the side with continuous (unbroken) lines, the pilot or operator should do what?

options.text: Proceed across the lines without stopping — they only apply to manned aircraft
Stop and do not cross without clearance from the tower
Slow down and cross if no aircraft are on final approach
Flash lights to signal intent to cross

explanation_correct: Runway hold-short markings consist of four yellow lines — two solid (continuous) and two dashed. The solid lines are on the side that requires stopping; you must stop and hold short until cleared by ATC. The dashed side indicates you are exiting the runway.

explanation_distractors.A: Hold-short markings apply to all operations on an airport surface.
explanation_distractors.C: You must have positive ATC clearance to cross a hold-short line — situational awareness alone is not sufficient.
explanation_distractors.D: Light signals are for communication when radio fails — hold-short lines require ATC verbal clearance.

question_text: You are operating a small UAS northeast of a nearby airport. A pilot announces on CTAF that they are departing runway 36 using a right-hand traffic pattern. Will the aircraft conflict with your operation?

options.text: No — runway 36 departs to the south, away from your position
No — right traffic keeps the aircraft south and west of the airport
Yes — the aircraft departs north then turns right (east), directly over your northeast position
Only if your UAS is above 400 ft AGL

explanation_correct: Runway 36 is oriented toward a heading of 360° (north). Departing runway 36 with a right-hand traffic pattern means the aircraft climbs northbound, then turns right (east) on crosswind, then southeast on downwind. This path goes directly over the northeast operating area.

explanation_distractors.A: Runway 36 takes off heading north, not south — runway 18 departs to the south.
explanation_distractors.B: A right turn from runway 36 takes the aircraft east and northeast, not south or west.
explanation_distractors.D: Traffic pattern altitudes are typically 800–1,000 ft AGL — any UAS operating in the area is a potential conflict regardless of altitude.
